text:
Delicious, but needed enhancements. I added 1/2 cup finely chopped red bell pepper, 10 shakes of Worcesteshire, more garlic, seasoning salt, splash of light soy, dried parsley, a whole egg not just the white. (For those that say your patties fall apart..I have a trick...You add the yolk of the egg as it helps to hold the mix together even when you have them flat as possible. Also put a light coating of flour on the patties just before you cook them ensuring that you shake off the excess flour. The flour helps form a light, crusty exterior and holds the patty and makes it easier to flip.) The egg yolk and extra bell pepper meant I had to add more breadcrumbs and for those who say their mix is sticky, you should probably add more crumbs anyway. How well they hold together in you hand is how well they hold on the pan. Juicy and very tasty.

text:
I grilled these on my George Foreman grill, however, I was concerned that the grill would cook the burgers too fast (no heat control).  So what I did was put the burgers on the cold grill, then plug it in.  15 mins later, the burgers were perfect! I cooked three and froze the rest...can't wait to see how they turn out!

text:
I am on a low cholesterol diet.  I am also a carnivore.  I love meat, but have been trying to cut down on fats & load up on fruit, veggies and the occasional red meat.  I found this recipe to be really good with the following additions: 1)  added a few drops of hickory seasoning liquid smoke  2)  add a few drops of Worcestershire sauce, 3) add a small, plastic package of soy sauce, leftover from a Chinese restaurant. This will guarantee that these babies will taste like beef.  I tried this on my equally carnivorous roomie, who proclaimed that due to my dilgent efforts, some can be fooled into thinking they're eating a Quarter Pounder, no cheese, extra onion.  Speaking of onion, shred fine with a shredder.  I used parsley from my garden.  Good going, Trudi!

text:
These burgers were scrumptious! I'd take them any day over regular hamburgers! (The husband, who's a big turkey fan, adored them too). When I made them, I substituted onion powder for chopped onion, left out the garlic, and added a few tablespoons of soy sauce, a couple teaspoons of worchestershire, and a few shakes of hot sauce. I also used Lawry's seasoning salt instead of regular salt. And I used italian-style bread crumbs. I put these on the grill, and sprinkled a little garlic powder and a little more worchestershire sauce on them as they cooked. I served them topped with lettuce, red onion, ketchup, and mustard, and they were so flavorful and juicy! Some other users said they added mushrooms to keep the burgers from being dry, but i found that the worchestershire will do the job just fine, and adds better flavor!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe three times...the first time I followed the directions exactly as written and thought that the burgers came out pretty good. The second time (after taking the advice of other users) I added a splash of liquid smoke, a splash of worcestershire sauce, and a splash of soy sauce. This recipe was a little tastier. The third time was definitely the best....instead of 1/4 cup of bread crumbs, I used 3/4 cup of Italian bread crumbs. I used one whole egg instead of two egg whites. I omitted the teaspoon of salt and added 2 Tablespoons of soy sauce instead. I added the splash of liquid smoke and worcestershire. Instead of trying to peel and mince the clove of garlic, I added 1 teaspoon of minced garlic out of the jar. The rest of the recipe (onion, parsley, pepper) I kept the same. Finally...I tried to pan fry the first two times, but grilled them on the BBQ the third time....10X better flavor! The one thing I learned is that you MUST spray the hell out of the grill with Pam to keep the patties from sticking.

text:
Delicious! I used fresh bread crumbs (this helps with the dryness problem others complained of) and seasoned it with a little bit of Italian seasoning.  They were really juicy. 

I was also careful to shape them gently (with a slight indentation in the center so that it would not "puff") and not press down on them during cooking, so they retained more juices.

text:
I have now made this recipe twice, and it was delicious both times.  The first time I had enough left over to make a meatloaf as well.  I combined some tomato sauce, brown sugar, salt and worcestshire sauce and poured it over the loaf in the pan before baking it.  It was great.  I would highly recommend this recipe to someone who may have tried turkey for burgers, but were turned off by the bland texture and taste.  This recipe overcomes all those issues, and is lowfat and healthful, too.  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Oh my goodness! This recipe is worth more than 5 stars! I made these burgers this evening...they were flavorful and moist! I did make some changes, I halved the recipe as the package of turkey was only a pound and a half. In addition, I used 2 cloves of garlic and 1/4 c of chopped onion as I love those flavors. I used a handful of parsley which I did not measure and one whole egg. I also used panko breadcrumbs 6TBS. In stead of salt and pepper, I used Montreal Steak seasoning within the mix and sprinkled lightly on each side when I put them on my outdoor propane grill. Thank you for this fantastic Turkey Burger recipe! This one is truely a keeper!

text:
I gave this 5 stars using this as a base for the recipe I ended up making.  I basically used all the ingredients listed but had to adjust for 1 lb of turkey to make 4 burgers for 2 ppl.  I sauteed my onion and garlic in a little Smart Balance spread first before adding to the meat and added about a tsp of rubbed sage also.  Used Slap Ya Mama seasoning instead of salt and pepper (if you can't find that, Tony's would also work).  Make sure to use a good bit of seasoning as turkey can be pretty tasteless otherwise.  I used one whole egg as well. And added a little worchestershire sauce.  Yea they're pretty darn soft and hard to handle at first, but if you get them formed and in the pan, fry  on medium to med low heat and start flipping occasionally when they're firm enough to flip, two at a time depending on your pan size.  They turned out so super juicy!  Best turkey burgers I've made yet!  Highly recommended :)

text:
My husband and I have been relying on this recipe for several years now and I thought I should give it the rating and review it deserves! Some comments about my experience with this recipe:
1) If I am making the recipe for a small crowd I still use the full sized recipe and easily have frozen uncooked burger patties to throw on the grill another time.  They grill up just fine popping them on there frozen.
2) As someone who loves to cook flavorful meals-I have struggled with a lot of dietary restrictions, allergies, etc and have a toddler to whom I am determined to give the benefit of healthy food.  These burgers are healthy to begin with, but they are also easy to make EVEN HEALTHIER.  For example, many times I have substituted the bread crumbs for uncooked old fashioned oats and have tossed other things like a little flax meal or wheat germ in them too.  
3) These burgers are great on a bun piled high with veggies and condiments, split in half and eaten rolled up in a tortilla, or open faced/without the bun altogether.  
As a parting comment-we always find these burgers juicy and flavorful.  In other words, they do not disappoint! 
Whether you use any of my two-cents-worth here or not, I hope you give these a shot!

These are fantastic! To my frustration, when I was in the middle of making these, I realised that I ran out of eggs! I added some milk instead and crossed my fingers  for the best. With some gentle handling, they actually ended up holding nicley.  The only additions I made were to add a dash of hot pepper sauce, worcestershire sauce, some tyme and a pinch of cumin.  Served them up greek style with melted feta, home made tzatziki, chopped kalmata olives, sundried tomatoes, red onions, spinach leaves and fresh tomatoes.  So good! Thanks for posting this great healthy alternative! :)

text:
I have never made or eaten a turkey burger in my life and neither has my husband, but these were "actually delicious".  We had no clue what to do, but I could see from the recipe and the reviews that this did need a little tweaking.  I had 1 pound of ground turkey, so I used 1/2 an egg yolk and a few tablespoons of italian style bread crumbs.  Instead of diced onion I used 1 tsp. of dried minced onion, 1 tsp. of dried parsley, 1/4 tsp. of salt, 1 clove of minced garlic, a dash of black pepper, and added 1 Tbsp. of worcesterchire and 2 tsp. of liquid smoke.  They were a little on the dry side, maybe because we cooked them too long (first timers) or because that's the consistency of turkey meat (dryer than beef).  Whatever the case they're good for you and we'd be up for trying them again.

text:
4.21.11 ... https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/39748/actually-delicious-turkey-burgers/ ... These were actually good!  :D  Of course, all the turkey burgers I've tried here I've liked.  Just some more than others.  Anyway, these did taste more like beef than the others.  Let me explain a little more that statement.  They didn't taste like great hamburgers, but burgers.  Unseasoned, kinda plain burgers; but still like beefy burgers.  I didn't try to fool anyone.  Next time, for kicks, I might.  :D  What I did:  1#ground mixed turkey; 2T plain bread crumbs; 1/8t onion powder (tried cooking onion inside before & they didn't cook, just heated); 1/8t each salt, pepper, garlic powder, liquid smoke, worcestershire, soy; 1T dried parsley. I meant to add 2T mayo for the egg whites, as suggested for moistness; but I forgot.  It seems adding mayo would've only made them oily since they were already moist.  One thing I always do with burgers of any type (including fish), is put them in the freezer a while - twenty or more minutes - before cooking.  It helps keep their shape & retain moistness. Note4Me:  Per most helpful review, sub mayo for egg whites.  Read more.10.12 After review w recipe: Added 1/4t liquid smoke & worcestershire, & although the others were good, I think more of these ingredients made it better.  Still didn't add mayo or egg at all. 3/13 1 1/2# mixed turkey; 1/4c plain breadcrumbs; 1/4t liquid smoke, salt, onion powder, garlic powder; 2T worcestershire; 1/2t fresh black

I always get frustrated at reviews which don't rate the recipe and instead rate the recipe according to the modifications that they have made to it... I can't lie.. I don't know how the recipe is without the modifications of worchestershire, soy sauce, hicory smoke, seasoned salt, extra garlic and extra onion.  The modified recipe I can give 5 stars to.  I am not a fan of turkey burgers, but I think without the mods it would have been a 4 star which is worthy, but why not modify it to make it rave-worthy?  I love the modified recipe.

text:
I've made this so many times as the recipe is written over the years and everyone loves them.  They freeze well too.  When my 81 year old father comes to visit, he can't eat anything green due to the Vitamin K interacting with his blood thinner medication.  So when he comes I substitute celery leaves for the parsley leaves (yes I realize they are both green and thus have vitamin K in them, but his doctor says the celery is not as bad as the parsley).  Either way they are good.

text:
A great recipe for otherwise dry but very healthy ground turkey. I used Shady Brook extra lean ground turkey; added more fiber and healthy fats by replacing the bread crumbs with flaxseed meal; and  to compensate for omitting *seasoned* bread crumbs, added 1 teaspoon of fresh crushed rosemary. I finished them by melting 1oz each of Monterey Jack cheese over each. While not on a diet but enjoying the benefits of my new healthy cooking, my husband thought they were unexpectedly flavorful and juicy. Thank you Trudy for the standard in turkey burgers!

text:
These turkey burgers were actually delicious.  When my husband and I were almost finished eating dinner, I asked him what he thought about the turkey burgers.  He said, "They're turkey?!"  Enough said. =] I used 2 lbs of turkey, 2 handfuls of Italian seasoned breadcrumbs, 3 cloves of garlic, 1/2 small onion, a whole egg in lieu of 2 egg whites, dried parsley, and salt and pepper to taste.  I formed 8 patties, and let them chill in the fridge for about an hour or so.  Then they were grilled on a preheated Foreman for grill 3 minutes, turned over, and grilled for 2 more minutes.  Juicy burger perfection.  Thanks so much!!

These were very good! I've never had a turkey burger I liked, but I'm sold on these. Even my VERY picky 3 yr old ate it! It was so nice to sit at the dinner table w/ my 5 children and hubby and not hear one complaint! That's worth more than 5 stars in my book! I only had 1/2 the turkey, and I actually forgot about this while I was making them and ended up adding the same amount of ingredients to it. oops! I also ran out of bread crumbs (grrr!) so I seasoned some panko crumbs and used those instead. Then I coated the outside of the formed burgers in the seasoned panko crumbs. Delicious!! A keeper for sure. My hubby said he enjoyed these just as much, if not more, than regular burgers! Oh yeah...I took the advice of others and added a few dashes of low sodium soy sauce and worcestershire sauce. :)

text:
I followed this recipe quite closely, with the exception of the parsley.  I used (Italian bread crumbs) which consisted of some dried parsley, so I didn't add any fresh parsley. (I highly doubt that had anything to due with how these turned out).  I cut the recipe in half and used a whole egg instead of whites as suggested by many of the reviews.  Unfortunately these were borderline inedible.  These lacked flavor, a lot of flavor, and the texture was something that I couldn't get past. This recipe needs a lot of tweaking, to say the least.  I see now why the majority of people added different flavor enhancing ingredients, but I wanted to try this without customizing it.  Big mistake.  With that in mind, the title of this recipe may need some rethinking.  If duplicated exactly, "delicious" definitely doesn't come to my mind.

userID:
2800623
Display Name:
maegena
isPro:
False
followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/467673.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've had this recipe in my box for a while now...Husband and I have been trying to eat healthier and I've been substituting turkey for ground beef in most of my recipes, but I was just very hesitant about a turkey burger...I finally decided today that I would give it a try...And we were both very pleasantly surprised! He could NOT believe it when I told him it was a turkey burger! He even said that he'd love to have another one...That's a HUGE compliment!  The recipe as is I give 4 stars (maybe even 3). I think though that it needs a little bit of love to be 5 stars. I read through reviews and followed some advice and the outcome was great! I scaled the recipe to serve 4 because there's just 2 of us...I used a whole egg instead of just the white, and I used 3 times as much breadcrumbs as the recipe called for...I used seasoned salt instead of just salt and used a tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce. So good...  The only thing was that I thought they needed a little more breadcrumb...They had a hard time sticking together. I saw in a few reviews to dip the patties in flour before frying...I tried that on one of the patties, didn't think it helped it hold together...and the ones without flour actually browned like a normal hamburger...the one with flour just had a weird texture to me...So I'd add more breadcrumb and skip the flour.   Thanks so much for the recipe...These are actually delicious!

Really good.  My husband won't even let me buy our usual brand of frozen turkey burgers anymore.  These were very moist (using low fat turkey, not the 99% fat free kind, which may make it a little drier).  I used dried parsley (reduced the amount by a third), and added Worcestershire sauce to the patties while they were cooking (didn't measure just dumped some on top of the patties, I always add worcestershire and sherry when cooking with ground turkey to give it more of a beef taste.) I also followed another review of chilling after making the meat mixture so that the flavors blend better.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were awesome. I must say the nice thing about this recipe is that it truly is a basic recipe. For someone who isn't familiar with making homemade burgers, but is an experienced cook, I found this to be very helpful. I followed the main components of this recipe (the ratio between the turkey:bread crumbs:egg), but altered the rest of the recipe slightly. Number one, I was oddly out of onion, so I used dried onion flakes. I used dried parsley (also do to the lack of it in my kitchen), and added dried basil, lemon pepper, and crushed red pepper flakes. I also used the salt, keeping it to a very small amount because the seasoned bread crumbs should have that covered. I served this on a whole wheat bun, and with perhaps one of the best burger toppers- grilled pineapple- amazing! (To grill it, I just used the pan I made the burgers in for about 1 minute on each side). All I can say is wow.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a nice, simple recipe - and one that's easy to personalize.
I've been making (and enjoying) a similar burger for years.  I use one pound each of ground turkey and ground chicken.  Add 1/4 cup Southwestern flavored Eggbeaters, 1/4 cup bread crumbs, one small finely chopped onion, 1/4 teaspoon cajun seasoning, 1/8 teaspoon ground black pepper finely chopped fresh parsley and fresh oregano (about 1/8 cup combined). Mix in 8 ounces of Mexican or Taco seasoned shredded cheese and 1/4 cup of chopped hot pepper rings (from a jar). Form into 8 patties.
We never make beef burgers anymore.

A good healthy burger. Giving 4 stars because they need a lot of extras - I used oregano, creole seasoning, roasted garlic, worcestershire, liquid smoke, and frank's red hot sauce. Also used 2 whole eggs instead of whites to get a better consistency - still healthy. Makes 12 good-sized burgers.

text:
I had a few issues with this recipe. I scaled it down to serve 4 as I wasn't about to take a gamble with 3 pounds of turkey, before testing the results out. Turns out this is one of those recipes that doesn't scale down successfully. Now calling for 5/8th of an egg white, I just put one whole egg in. The rest wasn't too hard to deal with, but I just found the result was dry and rather flavorless burgers. I see that many rave reviewers added a variety of enhancements. Not sure just what this needs, but I wouldn't make it again as written.

text:
This burger is good, but try this....Since the Turkey Burger is such a dry burger, I always replace the egg, with 1 1/2 table spoone of olive oil mayo or just plain mayo. The oil and egg base bind and add moisture. Try it!!!!!!!Also, decrease your salt with adding Mayo:) Much healther....One more thing, I replace the parley with Tarragon. It's a much better flavoring for poultry meat.

text:
Delicious! I just made these burgers for dinner, huge hit! Even my 2 year old, who refuses to eat hamburgers gobbled this up! Very moist burgers-unlike some of the reviewers I did not have a problem with the bread crumbs drying out the burgers, these were very juicy. I did make some changes to mine though. I cut the recipe in half because I only have a family of 3...this made 5 patties which was plenty. I added in some red pepper flakes, ground mustard, 10 shakes of Worchestershire, used seasoning salt instead of regular, and used a whole egg instead of just the white. I also grilled the burgers, which I think sealed in the juices really nicely! Topped with some american cheese and served with homemade french fries-delicious quick meal! Thanks so much for this recipe!

text:
Our family loved this recipe.  I tweaked it some:  I adjusted the recipe for 2 lbs. of ground turkey, added two shallots instead of the onion, added approx. 2 tsp. of honey, 1 1/2 tsp. of mustard. 2 tsp. of brown sugar, a few shakes of worcest. sauce, ground cumin, sea salt, approx. 2 shakes of cayenne pepper.  I made sure my oil was nice and hot to give the burgers a nice browning, I browned each side then turned the flame down to medium low.    I also forgot to put the egg in until the "second batch" I didn't notice a difference.  These burgers were juicy and delicious. I served on whole wheat hamburger rolls with chipolte mayo. So delish!! Our whole family enjoyed.

text:
Great starting point! It is very hard for me to get my boys to embrace ground turkey as a substitute for beef in anything, but I love them enough to keep pushing! Scaled the recipe to four servings and read alot of reviews which resluted in loving what I ended up with! Added finely chopped red pepper, chopped fresh cilantro (instead of parsley), (1) whole egg, a few shakes of worcestershire & light soy sauce, Mc Cormick Montreal Cix seasoning, I added the bread crumbs at my own discretion. The light layer of flour added to cover the patties I thought was key. My whole family loved this including my (10) yr. old son & his friend! I did put the patties into the fridge to firm up and made sure my oil was nice and hot before adding to the skillet. Thank you Trudi, I will make this recipe again!

text:
I made this twice. Once as the recipe states and the other using the suggestions from others. As the recipe is, it's a bit bland and dry and only worthy of a 3 star rating. Preparing this with a complete egg and adding Worcester sauce made it wonderful.  Additionally, turkey does NOT need to be cooked to 180 degrees. It's overcooked and thus dry. Cooking until the internal temperature is 165 will yield the best results.

text:
FANTASTIC!! I halved the recipe-worked great. Omitted onions & substituted onion powder, added 1 tsp. worc. sauce & 1/4 tsp. crushed red pepper flakes & 1/8 tsp. cumin for smoky flavor & spice. After combining, I put mixture in fridge for 1/2 hr. to get flavors going. Also makes it easier to form the burgers. TIP: Coat spatula w/olive oil for easier transfer to the grill.Put on a gas grill over medium heat for 6 min. per side. Melted provolone cheese just before taking off the grill.Topped with fresh avocado slices (YUM!)sliced sweet onion & Heinz chili sauce. This recipe got my 15 yr old daughter to try avocado for the first time, her comment- THIS ROCKS!!

text:
A big YUM! I added a little grated parmesan to this recipe as well as more garlic (and we always sprinkle Montreal steak seasoning on any burger). To keep them nice and juicy I browned them well in my skillet, then added just a little water at the end of cooking, put the lid on and let them steam for about 5 min. OMG they were delish!

text:
I did cut this recipe down to 4 servings and used the proportional amount of ingredients.  The burgers needed more flavor. I only modified two things: 1. I added a few shakes of Worcestershire 2. I used the whole egg not just the white. The burgers came out very juicy but were lacking flavor. Also I formed my patties and put them in the freezer for about 30 minutes. They held together perfectly when I put them on the grill. I will definitely make this recipe again, but will add some seasoning salt, more Worcestershire sauce, and some onion and garlic powder. Overall good base recipe.

text:
Great recipe.  I've made these about 50 times and always slightly "tweak" the recipe.  Like other reviewers have suggested, I always use a whole egg instead of the two whites.  I also add about a teaspoon of worcheshire sauce and about a teaspoon of soy sauce.  Finally, to keep the patties from sticking to the grill, I pour flour in a shallow bowl and coat the patties before grilling.  This keeps the burgers from sticking.  We prefer these burgers to beef burgers - they're that good.

userID:
8796241
Display Name:
chope
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
45
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The amount and size of diced  onion is critical.  If too much or especially-- too large, the patties crumble. should be diced on a scale similar to the ground meat. Up to 2 Tbl-spoons per pound meat works; which is a bit more than the recipe calls for. I'm also adding a cap full of liquid smoke per pound.
I'm grinding boneless/skinless chicken breast for less fat. looking online what commercial meat producers add to compensate for low fat meat in burgers and sausage,  I settled on adding 1/2 ounce (dry weight) textured soy protein per pound. I mix all my dry and vegetable components in a small bowl, (including bread crumbs and DRY parsley) add water a bit at a time till everything is nicely hydrated. with just barely a bit of standing water at the bottom of the bowl. Add egg white, mix and add this mixture to the meat as I'm grinding it. This minimizes excess kneading of the mix after it's ground.
Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
6533562
Display Name:
DCain
isPro:

29

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a favorite among my family of meat eating men! We have served this to guests and always get rave reviews! These turkey burgers will surprise and satisfy even the most traditional beef-burger-lover in your life!
This recipe is delicious as-is, but each time I make them I try to add a little personalized twist to make them a little different. Some of my favorite additions include: 1-1.5 cups of chopped baby bella mushrooms, 1 cup feta cheese, handful of pitted and chopped kalamata olives, dash of worchestershire sauce, dash of cayenne, dash of powdered mustard. The mushroom addition is my favorite trick to use when trying to stretch the recipe into more patties in order to feed more hungry mouths! Always a hit! The fresh parsley and onion are non-negotiable in my opinion! Sometimes I do sub fresh garlic for garlic powder, however. The breadcrumbs I add only as-needed to get the patties to the correct consistency.

I made these today with extra lean all white ground turkey. I added a teaspoon of smoke flavoring and some minced onions to the ground turkey. I cooked them on an indoor grill, and topped them with a dijon mustard/mayo combo, extra sharp cheddar, and lettuce/tomato/red onion. These were great, I could eat these everyday if all turkey burgers tasted like this! Served them with a side salad and baked sweet potato fries. Thanks for the great recipe!

userID:
5838596
Display Name:
dl
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love turkey burgers and never thought I would.  I would modify this recipe as follows:

I only make 6 and cover them in plastic wrap and then put in a freezer bag for later use.

Mine is simple - use plenty of diced onions (almost a whole small onion) - they keep the burger moist - and half of a small green pepper chopped fine.  I add about 2 tbs. of Worchestershire sauce; a few drops of Texas Pete; a few drops of olive oil; sprinkle of Montreal Steak Seasoning; and salt. 

I then form them into FLAT patties w/a hole punched in the middle so they will cook evenly.  They freeze beautifully and defrost quickly.  Moist and delicious as a "faux" burger.

text:
This is an awesome recipe, and is "actually" delicious.
I've been counting calories, and the 99% lean ground turkey is a great source of low fat protein...but it definitely needs a flavor boost.  I had 1.25 lbs on hand, and scaled the recipe accordintly.  I did use a medium sized shallot in place of the onion, and a whole garlic clove.  I also added a T of basil paste along with a pinch of rosemary.  Cooked it on the grill (next to my husband's beef burger), and it was the first time I didn't have burger envy.  Juicy and delicious--cooked to 170 degrees (white meat turkey).  Thank you for contributing this recipe!

text:
Based on other reviews I added one whole egg instead of the two egg whites, doubled the bread crumbs, used Lawry's instead of the salt and added 10 drops Worcestershire Sause, one shake regular soy sauce and about 3 drops of liquid smoke.  Laid burgers in some more bread crumbs on either side and dimpled the middle before placing in pan. Certainly cannot tell it is turkey!  Picky beef loving husband (and when I mean beef, we are used to fresh raised beef from the farm) approved.  It certainly isn't the same as beef, but it is a nice break from the usual burger. Will make again.

text:
These were very good!  I wouldnt say they were "better" than a burger - because they are very different than a burger, but are great. I made several changes after reading a lot of reviews.  Used whole egg rather than egg white, added Worchestershire sauce and soy sauce.  Added red pepper flakes, used Lawry seasoning salt for my salt, and doubled the bread crumbs. Also did coat in flour before pan frying. Topped with pepper jack cheese, lettuce, tomato, pickle, onion, ketchup and mustard.

text:
This was a very good recipe.  It gets just the four stars because it really does need the extra flavoring of the Worcestershire and soy sauce.  I tried it twice.  The first time with the extra sauces and my family loved it.  The second time I tried it as the recipes states exactly without anything extra and they were just alright.  So, pretty much if you're going to try this recipe I suggest going the route everyone else is going and add the Worcestershire sauce and soy sauce.  I don't know about the liquid smoke though.  I didn't try it.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/64882.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were very good.  I did change a few things according to other reviews. I added liquid smoke, soy sauce, and worcestershire sauce.  I didn't measure it just added a little at a time till it smelled good.  I did add a little more than 1/4 cup bread crumbs to help with the stickiness (it was still pretty sticky though). Did not use fresh onions but added some dried minced onions into the mix.  Used two cloves of garlic and a little garlic powder.  Also used egg beaters for the egg and seasoned salt instead of regular salt.  I did a slight coating of flour and Montreal Steak Seasoning (McCormick) to the formed patties.  I cooked them on my George Foreman (wanted to grill them outside but was afraid they would fall apart).  Served these with sauteed mushrooms.  Everyone ate them up.  Teenagers ate two of them, which makes them a hit at my house.  Will definitely make these again and again.

New Year, new changes. Substituted this recipe for our usual hamburgers. I did use 10 shakes of Worchestershire Sauce and pureed the onion to hide it. Used fresh homemade whole wheat bread crumbs and didn't add any additional seasonings to compinsate for the seasoned bread crumbs it called for. It WORKED! The burgers were very moist and tasted very good. Topped some with reduced-fat cheese. We had the leftovers for lunch the next day.

text:
Yummy!  I've actually only eaten turkey burgers at Red Robin's, and they were really, really good, so I was looking forward to making my own.  They tasted great!  I only made two and didn't bother scaling the recipe for two, I just mixed the meat with however much dried parsley, garlic powder, onion powder, bread crumbs (almost a whole slice's worth), salt and pepper as looked good.  And I used a whole egg white.  I thought they were better than normal hamburgers!  The only thing is next time I'll add more seasonings and although they are good on a bun with ketchup and mustard, the condiments cover up the flavor of the burger so I recommend just eating them with lettuce, tomato and maybe make them into turkey cheeseburgers.  Oh and I used my George Foreman grill and formed the patties on the grill.

country:
None
text:
These were really good turkey burgers. The only thing is, there is no need to cook ground turkey to 180. 165 is the minimum safe cooking time. Cooking to 180 (or higher, which is always an easy mistake to make) could have contributed to the dryness some complained of. Also, if the burger seems to wet, just add more panko. I've made these four times on my gas grill. The two times I didn't grease the grates, the burgers stuck. The times I did grease, they came off without sticking.

text:
I never used to buy ground turkey because it never tasted good to me and it always was "tough" next to just plain chicken.  Then I tried this recipe.  I love it.  It makes so many burgers and they are so moist.  I cook them all up and then bring them to work for lunch.  They reheat in the microwave beautifully and with a little mayo, lettuce, whatever, they are as good as when first made.  I have these more than I have regular burgers.  I never would have thought that that would happen.  I use Costco's pre-packaged turkey, and sometimes I add more breadcrumbs because the recipe is so moist.  I also just add a whole egg, rather than two whites.  It is a very forgiving and flexible recipe and one that friends have asked for.

Family loved them! The baby was even able to eat them. This is what I used:
1 lb ground turkey,
1/4 cup seasoned bread crumbs,
2 egg whites, lightly beaten,
1/8 cup chopped fresh cliantro, 1/2 tsp of minced garlic, 1/2 teaspoon salt (optional), 1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper. They were light, and healthy, and delicious.

text:
Very very delicious burgers. I make these all the time. I'll make up the 3 punds worth and freeze them to eat whenever I want. The only change I made to them was the seasoned bread crumbs. I use 1/8 cup because the seasoning in the breadcrumbs would overpower the over all taste of the burgers and make it too strong. By using have the amount, it made a ton of difference. Excellent recipe.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't think I've ever eaten a turkey burger in my life, but these were so easy to make and delicious!  The only thing I did differently was to add a splash of soy sauce, a splash of Worcestershire, and  sprinkle both sides with Montreal Steak seasoning before cooking.  I used a Tupperware hamburger press to shape the burgers and mine held together just fine.  I also covered the pan after flipping the burgers so they wouldn't dry out.  The burgers stayed very moist and juicy. De-lish! Thank you!

One simple change...to add a little flavour and moisture...saute the onion in a generous amount of butter first...saute until its very soft and golden...cool the onion and then add it in (butter and all)....delicious!!  I like more spices too...try thyme, paprika, or curry etc.  Great simple dish...the whole family loves them, with or without a bun!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
THE BEST BURGER! I absolutely loved this burger!! It was so moist,juicy,and flavorful. I too made a few changes: I only had 1 pound of ground turkey, so i used 2 heaping Tbls of seasoned bread crumbs, 2 tbls spoon of minced onion and green pepper, (i saute it first with cooking spray until soft and let it cool)used 1 egg white, a tbls of dried parsley cause thats all i had, 2 tbls chopped fresh cilantro (try this it really added a freshness to the meat!) 1 clove fresh garlic, 1 teas garlic powder, a dash of seasoning salt instead of salt and pepper. the other thing i added that no one else i saw added was 2 tablespoons of zesty italian salad dressing! SO DELICIOUS AND JUICY!! also, when you form the patties, press a little indent with your thumb in the middle of the patty, it helps it not puff up so much. i cooked mine for two min on each side in a med heat skillet, then finished it in a 350 degree oven for 5 min. (added cheese to melt the last 3 min) came out juicy and perfectly cooked! MUST TRY

I was surprised that I liked this recipe.   Not typically a big turkey burger fan, but I did doctor up the flavors a little like other reviewers suggested (added a little soy for example).   Despite extra bread crumbs and full eggs with yolks, I could barely form burgers with this mixture.   It was fairly mushy, but I managed to get a flattened something to the pan and it did cook up and make a strong patty....so in the end....it all worked out.   Very moist and healthy alternative to beef burgers.

Very good. I use this recipe as a base for meatloaf. It's so yummy. I use brown rice breadcrumbs and add Worcestershire, seasoned salt, garlic salt, a bit of onion/mushroom soup packet and a bit more salt and pepper. I have a nose like a wolf so I just sniff the raw meat until it smells delicious and then I pop it into a little dish and bake at 365 for approximately 1 hr or until my meat thermometer measures 180 degrees. Mmm. Thanks for this recipe! I use it often.

text:
I usually don't like turkey burgers, but these were quite good!  I followed some others' advice and used some freshly ground Italian spices, about 1/2 tsp, used a whole egg instead of the eggwhites, & added both soy sauce and worcestershire sauce. Since I didn't have any seasoned breadcrumbs, I used panko bread crumbs instead, increasing the amount to about 3/4 cup as well.  The red pepper from the Italian spices gave these a nice bite.  The recipe made 9 good-sized burgers; I cooked 4 and froze the rest.  Thanks for the recipe and tips everyone!

This was excellent!  I was short on time, so I used 1 lb ground turkey and eyeballed approximately 1/3 of the other ingredients.  I also used dried onion, parsley and garlic to save on time, used 1 egg white, and added a splash of Worcestershire sauce and liquid smoke.  I added a little more bread crumbs as well.  My DH (who had a beef hamburger), took a bite of mine and said that if he didn't know better, he would almost think it were a "real" hamburger.  I will make these again often!

These were very tasty! I did have a little bit of trouble with the patties staying together so added the yolk as mentioned. I also grilled mine and was worried about them falling apart and sticking to the grill. I used cooking spray on the grill and about 30 mins before grilling I placed the patties on some wax paper on a cookie sheet and placed them in the freezer. This helped with handling them on the grill!

Although I added some of my own ingredients, I give this 5 stars cuz I am thankful for Trudi for submitting this wonderful recipe and allowing people the chance to tweak it according to their own taste.  I read some reviews and did my own tweaking...added diced red pepper, whole egg, montreal steak seasoning, soy sauce and instead of parsley, I used cilantro.  I really enjoyed it...very juicy.  Remember not to press on the patties when they are cooking cuz. all the juice will seep out!

With some changes, these were excellent!  I added some dried cranberries, and used cilantro instead of parsley.  I used two whole eggs, and had to add some extra bread crumbs, and as another reviewer suggested, i coated the burgers with flour.  And we cooked these on the grill rather than on the stove.  We melted good quality blue cheese over the top, dressed the burger with cranberry sauce and caramelized mushrooms & onions.  The blue cheese and cranberry sauce complemented each other perfectly, it was delicious!

Okay, seriously, turkey burgers?  Yuck, right?  Not so fast...this is Actually Delicious!  I made almost exactly as written, but I used unseasoned bread crumbs, onion POWDER and added a tablespoon of Worchestershire sauce to the 1 pound of turkey (scaled back from the recipes 3 pounds).  My hubby added just a dash of seasoning salt at the grill.  I was annoyed that he was messing with them, but it was awesome!  So juicy, tender and great flavor.  No bun or condiments necessary.  Kids gobbled them up, too!

These were easy to make and my family loved them. Used onion powder instead of chopped onion in order to avoid the crunchy onion inside the burger issue. Other than that, made as per the recipe. Turkey tends to shrink a lot on the barbecue, so be sure to make your patties large diameter. Thanks!

text:
I love this recipe.  When I want a Turkey Burger, this is the recipe I grab.  I have made this recipe many times now.  I used Italian seasoned bread crumbs.  I do not like raw onions in foods like this, so I sauted them before adding it to the turkey.  I also added a few splashes of Worcestershire  Sauce.  I added extra bread crumbs until I liked the consistency.  I sprinkled both sides of the patties with more bread crumbs to help keep them from sticking.  I cooked the burgers on a George Forman Grill and they turned out wonderfully moist. Delicious on whole wheat buns.

I was skeptical, but pleasantly surprised at how tasty and moist these turned out. I used only 1 1/3 lbs. turkey (1 pkg.) for 2 of us, but left the measurements for the seasonings almost the same as listed b/c I was afraid they'd turn out bland.  I did add Worcestershire, per a recommendation and I used 1 whole egg instead of egg white.  The key is to cook them on med. slowly so they don't dry out.  I will make these again!

text:
I made these burgers for the second time tonight and they are still the best turkey burgers.  The first time I had just a quarter of a red bell pepper left over and decided to add it.  I put the bell pepper, onion, parsley and garlic in a little food processor and processed it really fine.  Awesome!  The second time I left out the bell pepper then realized I didn't have garlic so I used 1/2 tsp garlic powder.  Still really awesome.  Both times I cooked them on the grill and didn't have any problems with them falling apart.  You just have to make sure that they are completely done on one side before you decide to flip them.  Hope this helps.  Happy Cooking! :)

text:
Wow, it stands up to its name!  These really are "actually delicious turkey burgers"!  I hadn't made turkey burgers in years, but was in the mood for burgers and our store had a ground turkey 2 for 1 sale, so I decided I would give it one more try.  Glad I did because these were delicious!!  Half the ingredients and prep of my old recipe, and MUCH tastier!  I did leave out the parsley and onion (didn't have any), and had no egg (which I was a bit worried about), but they still held together great and had flavor.  I broiled mine on a wire rack over a baking sheet to cut down on fat, and they turned out perfect!  Pretty much fool-proof, I'd say.  Thanks for this recipe - its easy and delicious!

text:
I was not sure what to expect with these, this being my first attempt at Turkey Burgers.  They didn't remind me of a beef burger at all.  HOWEVER, they were excellent! This will become a new regular dinner as I can imagine it will taste great with a variety of sides.  I rated four stars instead of five because I made a few changes based on reading other reviews.  I added the whole egg,  added in some chopped green pepper (because I wanted to use it up, and it gave the burgers a little crunch), I made my own bread crumbs because I don't like the store bought ones (put a cubed up slice of bread in the oven then put it in the blender with spices) and I coated the pattys with flour before cooking.  Very Delicious!!

text:
This recipe has become one of the staples in our home. We love it, the kids love it, and we feel it's a healthy recipe that also has a fabulous taste!  We modify it per the other suggestions: I omit the salt and black pepper, and add 2T of soy sauce, (a generous) 2t of Worcestire sauce, and (a generous) 1t of hickory smoke flavor.  We cook it in a 450 degree oven: 12 minutes on the first side then flip them, then cook it until the internal temperature reaches 165 degress (only another 6 minutes or so).  We've served it a lot for guests, and everyone raves!

text:
This actually WAS a delicious turkey burger! I pretty much followed the recipes exactly with a few slight changes.

I didn't have fresh parsley, so I just used dried (used a little less than half the amount for the fresh parsley would have been). I also added some fresh baby portabello mushrooms (chopped up). I added a little bit of A1 Steak Sauce to give it a smokey flavor and a dash of soy sauce. (Maybe next time I'll use more of these sauces to add more zest to the dish.) Instead of pan frying it-- I just stuck the burgers in a broiler and watched to see when it was ready. (Topped the burger off with lettuce and ketchup, and served with sweet potato fries.) Yum yum yum! Oh yeah-- for the last minute of broiling, I topped the burgers off with a mixed variety of shredded cheese that I had. I will definitely be making this healthy alternative to a cheeseburger again!

Delish!  I made these on the George Foreman grill and not ONE drop of fat came out of that grill!  Amazing!  I felt like such a good mommy feeding my family something so low fat.  I was afraid for a moment when I saw how sticky and wet the mixture was, but they cooked up perfectly.  My 18 and 19 year old sons almost wouldn't try them, but they did and the picky one liked them more than the other one!  I was amazed.  Next time I might add fresh spinach leaves into the patties.  Oh, I also put a bunch more garlic in and didn't have breadcrumbs so I put a piece of bread in the toaster, then grated it with a cheese grater.

text:
Yum!  Okay, so I made quite a few changes (as per other reviewers, and some of my own...).   I cut the recipe to 5 servings, first of all, because I only had 1.3lbs turkey (how it's packaged here). Added a splash of soy and a splash of worcestershire to the mix, as well as a bit of tomato based chili sauce (like catsup, a couple of tablespoons).  This made the mixture a little too wet so I also added a bit of quick oats (about 1/4-1/3 cup).  With the extra stuff, this made 7 decent sized burgers.  Cooked these on the grill - delicious!  I will DEFINITELY make these again - once it's warm enough, they will likely become a weekly staple :)  Would have been equally good without my additions, probably.  Served on whole wheat buns with a little barbeque sauce.  Thank you for this awesome recipe!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
REALLY good.  Better than beef burgers.  I fudged this a little bit, keeping all the reviews in mind.  I started with the 1-lb package of regular 'ground turkey' (not breast) from Aldi.  Affordable and more moist than white meat alone.  From there, I had to play with amounts because it's only 1/3 of the amount of meat called for.  It made just the right amount for a family of four - we ended up with 5 good size burgers and my husband ate two.  Here's what I did:

Approx. 3 Tbsp. Panko crumbs.  
A few dashes of Worchesteshire. 
A few dashes of Soy Sauce.  
1 Jumbo Egg white.  
about 2 heaping Tbsp. Shredded Onions (used medium cheese grater, less than 1/4 of an onion).  
1 medium clove garlic, minced.  
A few dashes of our favorite Rib Rub seasoning.  
A slightly heaping 1/4 tsp. of Kosher Salt.  

 Fried on med-low on skillet then transferred to 350 degree oven to finish while I prepped burger fixings.  

The result was an amazing, delicate, light, flavorful, moist burger!  This will go down in our recipe book for repeated uses.

text:
I prepared these to go over rice for a Japanese style curry rice dinner. 

Adjustments to original recipe:

4lbs ground turkey (16 1/4lb patties)
Panko bread crumbs subbed for seasoned bread crumbs
Whole eggs subbed for egg whites
2 cloves garlic
1 1/2 tsp curry seasoning

text:
These were super good.  I didn't want to make 12 patties, so I used 2 lbs of turkey and adjusted the ingredients to approximates.  In place of the egg white, I used 1 whole egg.  Per some other reviews, I also added some soy, liquid smoke and worcestershire.  I will make these again and again.  

I'm not sure why the recipe calls for cooking to an IT of 185.  Poultry is safe at 165.  Even the ground turkey wrapper says to cook to 165.

Display Name:
Rita Lea

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2123679.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these double the thickness in a cast iron pan, for a more 'tavern' style burger. I highly recommend this to get a beautiful char on the outside. Then turn the heat down lower to get the inside cooked through, since we're talking turkey not beef, you don't want medium rare turkey. The parsley adds great fresh flavor and the egg white keeps them fluffier than using whole eggs. Also a tip for any recipe calling for a meat mixture, mix everything except the meat first, and then mix it into the meat. It mixes in a lot more evenly and easily that way.
Review:

5

region:

country:
None
text:
Awesome! These turned out juicy, moist and full of flavor. Instead of mincing the garlic, parsley and onion, I pulsed it to a paste/puree form in my magic bullet blender instead. This helped to breakdown each ingredient without messy chopping and allowed the meat to really absorb the flavor. I did add extra bread crumbs to offset the added moisture so we could grill them rather than cook them on the stovetop. They did not fall apart on the grill at all and were cooked for 4 minutes on each side over medium/high heat. 

Here were the changes/additions I made for 16 OZ OF TURKEY BURGERS ON THE GRILL:
Above ingredients plus
1 packet or 1 teaspoon of soy sauce
1 teaspoon of worchestershire sauce
1 whole egg
Puree the onion, parsley and garlic together before adding to the meat
1/4 cup Italian breadcrumbs
Combine all ingredients well, divide meat into 4 parts, roll into 4 patties, indent the center slightly, cover and put back in fridge for up to 3 hours before grilling.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2015-05-11T06:28:42.877
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
6750152
Display Name:
Bonnie K.
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
630
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made Turkey Burgers for years.  As I am a dump method person, I don't have an exact measure, but enjoy making them different every time.  The consistency should be a burger that you can put together into patties with your hands.  I use the whole egg and Italian bread crumbs to start and then add spices - such as Mrs. Dash's assortment but the Garlic one in particular.  I sometimes add extra basil or Italian seasonings.  I also will add either Parmesan cheese or some type of shredded cheese and stir that all together and then form them into patties.  I have found if I wet my hands together before forming the patties that they form up better. My family loves these and request them often.  I do them either inside or on the grill.  If they fall through the grates, then the mixture is too wet and you need to add more bread crumbs.  I use a turkey package from Aldi's - which is over a pound, so I usually use 1-2 eggs (and sometimes 1 whole egg and 1 egg white).  These are often requested at our family reunion get togethers. These can be made into gluten free burgers by using gluten free bread ground up and have fun experimenting with flavors.

text:
This is our go-to turkey burger recipe. The flavor is amazing and on the stove top, they are so easy to make. I opt out the bread crumbs since I'm yeast free but I add Italian seasoning and use the whole egg. I typically make these with parmesan roasted potatoes. Yum! We've made them on the grill before with tin foil and when they are pretty firm, add the directly on the grill for the marks.

text:
Like it says. Simple & delicious! It gets a five b/c you can add ingredients and it just gets better or keep it as is. I've added ketchup, worcester, & A1 sauce for BBQ and people loved them. Next time I'll place allum foil on grill b/c they cook fast and stick to grill otherwise. For me, baking on a pan yielded best results. No dryness b/c I used less breadcrumbs. I use two circular soup lids two shape my burgers to perfect consistency (wife's idea). I place freezer paper between two patties & freeze. They thaw out in 20 minutes when removed! Bravo to it's creator & thanks for sharing recipe!

text:
Because we're trying to cut out red meat in our diet, I tried this recipe. My adult children and their spouses and boyfriend were over and when I took the burgers out of the frig to put them on the grill my daughter made a face when I told her they were turkey burgers. She asked if I made real burgers. I told everyone the reviews were good and one woman's husband swore off beef burgers when tasting them. With all the food I made including my ribs, the turkey burgers were the hit! Some even chose to get seconds on burgers and "save" the rest of their food. YOU'VE GOT TO TRY THEM. They'll be YOUR new favorite. They are moist and flavorful with so few ingredients.

Added a bit of Extra virgin olive oil and they were the best! I've also used beef instead of turkey and still added the olive oil and they came out even better! This is a wonderful base recipe to add things too like a cheese (like feta - drop half the salt though) or if you want something spicy, a bit of crushed red pepper or finely chop any kind of spicy pepper (depending on how spicy you like - but still add the pepper because salt and pepper are the yin&yang of spices)

text:
Delicious, and so fast and easy!  I did make a few changes - added some Worcestershire, additional Italian seasoned bread crumbs, tripled the garlic, and used whole eggs.  I was out of fresh parsley and onion so I used dried, and after mixing let it sit 15 minutes so the onion would absorb some moisture.  I pan fried them and added a slice of cheese on top during the last minute or so of cooking. They were moist and very flavorful.  My husband commented on how delicious they were and asked to have them again the next night.  They will now be a regular on my list of dinner recipes!  Thanks Trudi!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6047500.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just love these turkey burgers! I added a little more breadcrumbs than stated because I found the mix was still too wet. A few tricks I could offer are; if you find your turkey mix is too mushy, once mixed, try putting it in the freezer for about half an hour to an hour to firm it up a little. Also, if you want to grill these but are afraid they won't hold up on the BBQ, try popping them on the frying pan for a couple minutes each side, they will bond together and be all set for the BBQ! Even my 4 year old son ate this up in no time flat and was pleased to have leftovers for lunch the next day!

text:
The best turkey burgers I've tried!  I cooked them in a George Foreman grill, they kept their shape and were perfect.  Very tasty!  There is no fat in the turkey so make them bun size, they will not shrink.  I made 4 patties and froze 2.  Later I cooked the frozen patties and they were just as good as the fresh and very convenient to just pull out of the freezer and grill.

country:
None
text:
Wow, these were so good. I have tried quite a few turkey burgers and due to using 93% lean or higher white meat turkey, they are typically on the dry side. I only had 1 lb of ground turkey, so I made 1/3 of a recipe. I was able to get 5 good sized burgers using a mashed potato scoop to portion them. I cooked them on the stove top as suggested. put the burner on about 7 and greased the pan with around 1 Tblsp of canola oil. I liked that they all fit. Only other change I made was mixing up my own store bought type seasoned bread crumbs to taste with basil, Italian seasoning, garlic salt and powder, onion powder, salt and pepper. I always do this as the flavor to me is just better. I served them on toasted GF whole grain buns. I will definitely make these again.

text:
I had better chefs than myself cook up turkey burgers I liked less than this one. Its a very quick and easy recipe, so much so that I can almost entirely place my boyfriend in charge of this one. I used 2.25lb of turkey instead of 3, but kept all the ingredients the same, I feel this allows it to be more flavorful while producing a few less patties. I think the turkey tastes great and makes for a much healthier option. I like to prepare this meal with non-traditional burger sides such as coconut rice in order to give the meal a different, more healthy feel. I've seen a few reviews mention issues with the patties sticking together, I had no issues whatsoever with this, perhaps because I used less meat, but I couldn't say for sure.

text:
I didn't follow the recipe exactly.  I only had 1 lb of turkey and so scaled it back a little.  However, I used the 2 eggs, about 1/2 cup bread crumbs and about 1/2 of a package of Lipton's dry onion soup mix.  The burgers turned out pretty good.  Instead of making them into patties, (the mixture was quite gloppy), I spooned globs into a little olive oil in a fry-pan and flattened and rounded them out to burger shapes.  That worked well.  Will probably make them again, as it's a good way to use ground turkey, which we like to have every now and then.

text:
Rather than using eggs as a binder, I prefer using salsa sauce. Not only is it a great binder but it is also packed with flavour. For one pound I use about 2 tablespoons. (If the meat was previously frozen, it may take slightly less).  The trick is to balance the moisture and the bread crumbs.  If you can form the burgers without falling apart then they  will be fine for grilling.

These were fabulous! Topped mine with some avocado, hot sauce, lettuce and a bit of (light!) mayo... yummy! They were not dry or bland (as some turkey burgers can get) AT ALL!!!
This recipe also makes quite a bit. I ended up with 15 patties, and since there were just 3 of us, I froze the rest. So convenient for impromptu summer cookouts!

text:
I cut this down to four servings and because I'm cutting back on unnecessary carbs and bread, I used grated parmesan cheese instead of bread crumbs and I needed a little more because my ground turkey was a little wetter, I guess. I kept the parsley but added a half batch of Stacey's Hamburger Seasoning (minus most of the salt) for extra flavor. This went over pretty well, not bad for three boys who balked at eating turkey burgers. I made actual burgers for the boys but I had my burger as is, with a side of my Fully Loaded Cauliflower Salad and Balsamic Mushrooms. NOM. I'll make this again for sure. EDITED: I forgot that I added 1/4 tsp. of Liquid Smoke, too at the last minute.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not sure why I haven't reviewed this recipe til now. I've made these burgers no less than 8 times since I found this recipe. It's really a go-to recipe for me. The texture and flavor of the burgers is very good. Be sure not to use a crazy ultra-lean ground turkey. I like that there is just enough flavor in these -- not trying to be anything other than a burger. Sometimes I up the garlic, but that's about it. Highly recommend. Definitely make a full batch. The three pounds of turkey typically makes only 8-9 burgers for me instead of the 12 in the recipe. These freeze beautifully as well. Make extra.

I made this recipe as-is with the exception of using a whole egg instead of just using the egg whites. I did not have any problems with the patties falling apart. Even though they did not taste like beef was beside the point, because turkey shouldn't taste like beef to begin with. They had a unique and good flavor of their own, and I would definitely make them again. I have made these 3 times as of this review, and again I have to say the overall flavor of these are great. These are officially a part of my recipe portfolio now.

text:
Ok, these are not better than beef but they are definitely the best ground turkey concoction I have ever had.  I don't usually care for ground turkey at all but these are a keeper.  If you have trouble with the burgers falling apart your onions might just be too big.  They need to be diced pretty small.  Or even grated in.  I served these on Arnold Sandwich Thins (100 calories for the whole roll!) and topped with lettuce, tomato, raw onion, and buffalo chicken marinade.  My husband gobbled them up.  Definitely a keeper!

The burgers were great.  I used approx. 1 lb. 95% lean ground beef and 1 lb. extra lean turkey (that is all i had in the freezer).  I used 1 whole egg instead of egg whites, fresh onion, dried parsley, garlic powder, salt, and pepper to taste. Then I sauteed some fresh mushrooms and topped the burgers off with fresh mushrooms.  My husband had no clue they were made with turkey and commented how great the burgers tasted.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUM! Who needs beef now? Based on the reviews I read, I made a few tweaks to the recipe. I used a whole egg instead of just an egg white. I used Italian style bread crumbs (which has dried parseley in it) and also added a dash of soy sauce in it. And I did not mix the garlic directly into the mix. Instead, I pan fried the meat and sauteed the minced garlic before putting the meat in. I also put a lid over while cooking the meat so the steam would help. Put it at medium heat and the patties cooked in about 5-7 minutes. Also did a slight experiment with my 2nd half of the meat and mixed a little bit of feta cheese in it. It turned out very flavorful. I served it with whole wheat buns and it was great!

When I told my kids I was making turkey burgers, they said "eeewww." But when they had these, they loved them & wanted seconds.  I added worcestershire sauce, as others suggested, but I think they would've been great without it. My husband made them a second time & added soy sauce, which he thought made them better. I will definitely make these instead of regular hamburgers from now on. Thanks for the recipe!

This was fantastic and all the posted tips were helpful as well. Both husband and son loved these as much as a regular burger. I've found that the tip on using a whole egg, versus whites only, did help keep things together and I used Italian seasoned bread crumbs as well as the onions, salt, pepper, garlic and onion powder for flavoring. A nice versatile recipe that you could probably add more of your favorites to as suggested in the other tips.

text:
These are great! We made our own breadcrumbs by pulling a piece of bread into smaller bits and putting into an oven at 225. Only need 1 slice for 1/4 c. We had to use dry parsley, but they still turned out great. With fresh parsley I'm sure it has lots more flavor. We also added some cayenne pepper for a little more kick. We also didn't have eggs, so we used 1 T. milled flaxseed with 3 T. water and let sit 1-2 mins. They were still awesome. We're waiting for the rest of our patties to freeze right now!

Definitely plan on making these again, it is hands down the best turkey burger recipe I have found.

These were really good turkey burgers - my bf loved them.  We cut down on the salt slightly and increased the black pepper (just personal taste), and the bead crumbs I chose were also garlic and herb flavored.  We cooked these on the grill, so I added a little more bread crumbs to make sure they would stick together (probably would have without them). I think the suggestions in other reviews to use seasoning salt and/or Worcestershire sauce would bump these up to a 5-star rating for sure.

text:
Trying to get healthy and tried these out - very very good and will be making these again. Followed the recipe exactly and added the suggestions of worsteschire, soy sauce, and lightly floured the patties. Even hubby, who was extremely skeptical, liked them. Served them with spicy sweet potato fries.  Update: I had frozen leftover patties and defrosted them in the microwave for dinner last night. They were soggy and would not hold their shape. I put far too much flour on them and it helped only a little.  I finally had to put them back in the freezer for a short time to firm up so they wouldn't fall thru the grate on the grill.  They came out fine, but definitely took extra time.  Just a heads up to you! :)

These are fantastic! Another variation that I've tried - turn them into meatballs by adding 1/4 cup parmesan cheese to the original recipe and a bit more breadcrumbs. Roll into meatballs,  brown them in olive oil in skillet, and then simmer in spaghetti sauce. Really, really good!

This recipe is so good!  My family loves this recipe!  I am watching my calories and my DH is diabetic, so this was PERFECT for us!  
I added a little soy sauce, worcestershire sauce & then to get in some more veggies I added green onion, yellow onion & spinach, all finely chopped. (I didn't have any parsley).  I forgot to add the bread crumbs the first time I made these and they still held together & did not fall apart.  The second time I made these with the bread crumbs and I honestly couldn't tell the difference.  They were delicious both ways!  It tastes like beef...only better I think!  Thanks so much for the recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My DH and I made these burgers for dinner tonight and the end result was pretty darn good, but we did make a few changes.  First, we scaled the recipe to 4 servings.  We also used minced shallot instead of onion and I sauteed the shallot with the garlic for a few minutes before adding to the turkey.  Lastly, following the advice of another reviewer, we added 1/2 tsp seasoning salt, 1 Tbsp worcestershire, 1 Tbsp of soy sauce, 1 whole egg and about 1/4-1/3 cup bread crumbs to the turkey mixture; we also grilled the burgers instead of frying.  The burgers ended up being very good and really moist but as my husband said...while they are good, they still would not replace his regular grilled burger.  EDIT:  I made these again and they turned out significantly better.  This time I used ground chicken, about 1Tbsp Worcestershire sauce, 1 small grated onion, 3 cloves garlic, 1 egg white and about 2 1/2 Tbsp of seasoned bread crumbs.  We did grill them again - and they were definitely 5 stars!

text:
We made these tonight and they were great. Looked at some of the other reviews for ideas and here is what worked for us. Follow the recipe then add 1/2 teaspoon kitchen bouquet, shaved the onion on a grater, 1/2 teaspoon soy and worcestire sauce, used seasoning salt, then put them in the fridge for about an hour to help them "firm" up for the grill. Awesome with all the regular burger fixins!

text:
This is a really good recipe that produces a very tender and flavorful burger.  I found it helpful to form the patties on a freezer or waxed paper lined cookie sheet and chilling them well before cooking in order to make handling them easier and to help them stay together and maintain their shape better.  Just as the title implies, these are actually delicious turkey burgers and the kids, ages 8, 10, 12, and 15, say they actually like them better than traditional beef burgers.  I am really pleased as these are so much healthier and fit the bill too!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So Im normally one that says make it as is and then adjust to your taste. However I think this is a basic enough recipe that you will find yourself playing with it. Turkey burgers have become a mid-week staple but I usually just buy fresh ready patties from the meat section (so $$$$!). Tonight I decided to try making them completely from scratch. My mixture made 11 patties with perfect thickness.  I used panko (had them already), 2 whole eggs, parsley, garlic powder, minced onion, Worchestershire,  garlic pepper and salt. I also added some leftover riced cauliflower that I wanted to use up. I wish I had spinach to add as well. But I mixed the ingredients well, formed patties, and let them sit in the fridge while I prepped the rest of dinner.  I pan fried them and they were so delicious!! Got rave reviews. Served with corn and green beans. So filling and soooo easy. I want to try Cajun style with diced peppers next. So yeah use this recipe as a base but for sure make to your familys taste!

These were excellent. My first time using ground turkey and I couldn't be more pleased with how they turned out. This is an excellent turkey burger. I generally use the 1 lb turkey trays so I adjust my quantities to 1 heaped tablespoon of breadcrumbs and 1 egg. text:
I've tried several turkey burger recipes and this one is our new favorite.  It's easy to prepare and tasty.  I followed the advice of a couple of other reviewers:  used 2 whole eggs rather than egg whites, doubled the bread crumbs and put the patties in the freezer for a couple of hours to keep them from falling apart.  I also added a little bit of fried chopped bacon.

Oops!  I didn't pay attention to the amount of turkey!  It called for 3 pounds and I had one pound.  I had already mixed the egg whites and spices.  So I used 1/3 of the mixture and it came out a bit dry.  But it was tasty and my hubby and 17-year-old son ate it and said they would eat it again.
Also, I didn't have breadcrumbs but improvised by crushing 3 Melba Toasts with my own added seasonings. Maybe that made it dryer? I'm no expert cook!
So I think I need to cut the whole recipe by 1/3 for my 1 pound of  turkey meat next time.

text:
Made these - but like everyone else- with changes.  I used an 85/15 turkey mix.  I used one egg with the yolk, 2 TBS of soy instead of salt, and a TBS of worstershire.  Because of these liquids, I used a cup of Italian seasoned breadcrumbs and they still were juicy.  I also used  a half TBS  of garlic powder instead of chopped.  I then patted the patties with flour on each side.  Delicious!

text:
We didn't have all of the ingredients on hand, so my review is a combination of what others have suggested and using what we had. I only had two pounds of turkey. I used onion powder instead of regular onion, plus one whole egg instead of egg whites. I used minced garlic from a jar and added dashes of soy and worcestershire sauce to keep the meat from drying out.  Because of the added liquid from the sauces, I also increased the bread crumbs to 3/4 cup. We decided to use our grill and the taste was FANTASTIC!  So easy and not too dry at all. Will definitely make again!

text:
These turkey burgers have quickly become a family favorite! We use 96% lean ground turkey (the 99% lean was a bit too dry on the grill for our liking). The only minor modifications we made were adding a few dashes of Worcestershire sauce to the mixture and using 2 whole eggs rather than using just the egg whites. 

To grill:

Oil the grill grates, sear for 2-3 minutes per side then finish on the cooler side of the grill using indirect heat until your thermometer reads 165F - juicy and delicious every time!

text:
We have never had turkey burgers before, but my family is always open to trying something new. I had two pounds of ground turkey in the freezer, and decided to try these burgers. I did add 1 tsp dry mustard, 2 tbsp. of soy sauce instead of salt, 2 tsp. of Worcestershire sauce, and a little extra garlic as suggested by other reviewers. I used a burger press, and got 7 burgers from the mix. The  mix was very liquidy, and didn't hole together very well, so I cooked them on Reynolds wrap in my Nuwave oven at 375 degrees for 5 minutes per side. The burgers got more solid as they cooked. We all very much enjoyed these burgers. My husband said he was surprised that they were as tasty and moist as they were.  I don't think we will give up our bison burgers, but this is a great change of pace.

text:
Very tasty, especially if cooked in a cast iron skillet.
We almost never eat ground turkey because ... well, it's boring ... and why eat a turkey burger when you can have a REAL burger?  So the other day I saw a RR recipe for a "turkey club with a twist" (a club sandwich with a turkey burger instead of sliced turkey) that I wanted to try but knew I needed to put a lot more flavor into the turkey itself and found this recipe.  I wasn't sure about the raw onion ... or the parsley, but I followed the recipe exactly and I am so glad that I did.
In the end I put together toasted white bread, mayo, lettuce, thick slices of tomato, crisp bacon, this turkey burger with melted cheddar and pepper jack ... it was SO GOOD!  (btw if you try this RR puts fresh guacamole on hers ... yuck)
I will absolutely make these again.

text:
I'm going to make some people mad because I changed the recipe.  Sorry...  Thank you to those who post their modifications.  I could tell by the original recipe that it could be improved upon based on my families likes & dislikes, so here goes:   I added Kinder's Organic Buttery Steak Seasoning-- I've discovered this recently & use it on practically all meat.  Also, a few shakes of tabasco, worchestirshire sauce.  Also, 1/4c yellow bell pepper & 1/4 c diced onion.  I absorbed the moisture from bell pepper & onions w/a paper towel to ensure the patties wouldn't fall apart.  I took the the advice of another reviewer & used a whole egg & dusted the patties w/flour to ensure the patties would form--great advice, this worked well!  This one is a keeper.

My picky eater of a man enjoyed this one! (I can't believe it). I adjusted the recipe for one pound of turkey as I am only cooking for two. My family usually has turkey burgers that my mom makes. Today I really wanted to make dinner for my family today, and my mom thought of turkey sliders. I found that these turkey sliders where delicious!! But my mom and I did tweak somethings in our convince. I used a tablespoon and a half dried parsley, instead of fresh parsley because that was all we had. Then to season the bread crumbs, we added about a tablespoon of Spice Island Organic Garlic & Herb Seasoning. We also used our Griddle Gourmet thing to cook our sliders (which is kind of like a large panini presser, but I'm sure you know what that was anyway), instead of a skillet. Your burgers where so yummy and juicy. Every time we had turkey burgers again, we would use this recipe. My whole family agreed on it. I hope you take my suggestions. It's okay if you don't...... they'll still be delicious. :) Mallory

I made it, and it was great! 
I didn't have all the ingredients, so I substituted some things.
I used a packet of turkey gravy mix to help with seasoning and juiciness.
Also, instead of making patties, I sprayed a large cookie sheet with cooking spray, spread out the turkey burger mix and then covered it with strips of bacon and baked it for the recommended cooking time.
I then cut it into squares to fit on bread (didn't have burger buns lol)
It was a very flavorful, juicy treat that me and my husband both thoroughly enjoyed!

Ive never eaten turkey burger before but now that I have.....I am fully converted. Ive had issues with ground beef being so fatty and those little gristle pieces in it. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1139139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not sure what happened with the critical review highlighted above. I've made this recipe dozens of times over the past several years and never had them 'melt' through grill grates. I can only assume they started fussing with the patties before the meat had cooked enough to release and be turned over. Or there was some ill-conceived alteration... you for sure need the binders, the egg and bread crumbs. This is a delicious recipe as written. I'm sure the many suggestions are great. I often season it with dried basil and occasionally with Stacy's hamburger seasoning from this site. I'll grill them or use our indoor/grill griddler. Three pounds of meat makes a lot of patties. If you don't eat them all right away, they freeze and reheat very easily for a nearly instant meal later. Microwave a frozen pattie for, what, a minute or two and it's ready to go on a bun. I've made a lot of AR recipes and this one is easily in my top 10, maybe top 5.

I have tried eating healthier but WOW I had to work hard to (choke) eat these.   If your expecting something as good as a real beef then don't look at these. Its just bland Turkey loaf on a bun.  I even gave it a good honest try.  The wife wanted ground turkey breast and that was around $8.00 per pound!  So I bought the regular and that was $6.00 and my best Burger beef is chuck 80/20 and makes the best ones.  All they need is salt pepper and an onion on top with melted cheese and what other condiments you might want.  I guess if you like this kind of stuff, more power to you.  The wife didn't even like them and I followed the recipe to the letter.  Oh well. She even claims to like groind Turkey.

This recipe is fantastic.  Like other reiewers, I addeda couple of extras my family likes.  Did the chopped pepper, hot sauce, worchester and soy. I also had a bit of leftover spinach and fresh rosemary from another recipe I was doing so I threw that in too. Spinache made no difference but the rosemary certainly did!!i  Best tip was giving them a very slight coating of flour.  They held together beautifully. . Will make these over and over again. One thing to note as another reviewer pointed out, turkey is bland so don't be afraid to season liberally. Thanks for the keeper!

text:
Yummy!  I added more garlic & also pepper for some kick.  I always like to add diced fresh mushrooms to turkey burgers because they add moisture.  Since ground turkey is so lean,  and they have to be grilled until well done, they can get dry.  For this reason,  ground turkey breast does not do well on the grill for me, so I stick to lean ground turkey, which includes some of the dark meat in the grinding, but is still very low in fat compared to beef burgers.

text:
Great tasty burger! I try to substitute turkey for hamburger a lot but most of the time it's never as good as the "real" thing. These, however, I enjoyed eating and they didn't make me miss beef. Success! I used dried parsley instead of fresh and added a little garlic and onion powder (in addition to actual onion and garlic). I think it has a good base flavor that could easily go with any sort of toppings. Didn't read the reviews until after I made it. I didn't have any problems with it being dry or bland. I find ground turkey to be very wet. It may depend on the fat content of your ground turkey. I just buy the cheap stuff, not the lean.

text:
Grilled the burgers!  Awesome!  Added more garlic, salt and pepper.  Secret for grilling is to coat  the burgers and grill with a little olive oil.  Preheat the grill to medium.  Put the burgers on and DON'T touch them for 5 minutes, cap it, THEN flip them for another 3 minutes.  ALSO don't work the meat  too much.
