text:
Yum! I didn't have breadcrumbs or eggs this morning when I was making.  So, for the binding, I mixed together 2t of ground flax seed with 2T of water, poured about half in.  Next time, I may try to mix in almond flour in place of the breadcrumbs, but I didn't think of that until too late.  :)

Also, I was blown away by the sugar content of the grocery store hamburger buns, so we made our own.  I was surprised by how easy this was (and how delicious they tasted)!  And, I was so grateful to not be giving my family unnecessary extra sugar. If you have some time, perhaps consider some reading about what the scientists have begun to learn about sugar and the way our bodies process it. Oh my.

Thank you so much for the recipe!

text:
Way to keep us from missing beef! So moist and yummy.

Minimal Changes:
Only made two 1/4 pound burgers
Added 1/2t soy sauce & 1/2t Worcestershire 
Subbed green onion for regular 
Subbed scrunched croutons for bread crumbs
Used most of both yolk and white of one egg
Crumbled some Havarti into the concoction

Baked up some fries and had a fantastic supper.

text:
These made the best turkey burgers we've eaten.  I love that it made a lot.  I froze the extras for another day.  I did adopt some other commenters' suggestions and a couple of my own.  I used 2 Tbs. soy sauce (instead of the salt), 4 tsp. dried parsley (instead of fresh), dried garlic (instead of minced), and added Worcestershire sauce, an extra egg, and bumped up the Italian seasoned dry breadcrumbs to 3/4 cups.  Seriously delicious!

I loved the flavour of these -- I added more garlic, and also some sriracha and soy sauce. I would've given it a 5 except that when I went to form patties I tried putting them between parchment paper and then they wouldn't come off!! They were so tasty they didn't even need cheese on them--just mayo, bbq sauce, lettuce and tomato! Yum!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1250559.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe several times.  It far improves any of the other turkey burger recipes I had tried.  It is excellent as it is but after the first few times, I modified it with extra onion (about double, finely minced) and used cayenne pepper instead of black pepper.  Once I used Lowry's seasoned salt in place of the regular salt.  It is delicious as written and even better IMHO with the modifications. Mix it in the morning and cook for dinner.  The burgers fall apart easily if not made hours ahead of time.  Same flavor, just easier to flip as a whole burger.

region:

country:
None
text:
I have used ground turkey as a substitute for beef in so many of my recipes, as my fianc cannot have red meats very much due to his high blood pressure. I have even made turkey meatloaf a few times with praise from my fiance. However, turkey burgers seem to get a bad rep for not being as good as beef burgers.  Given the rating on this recipe, I decided to give it a try.  I followed the recipe to the letter, and I have to say the turkey burger's bad rep still stands.  Even though I used the seasonings in the recipe, it didn't have a very good flavor, and wasn't as juicy as a beef burger is.  I guess if you are expecting it to taste as good as a beef burger, that is where the flaw is, because it tastes nothing like it.

text:
This recipe was very easy especially for myself who rarely cooks. This was my first endeavor making turkey burgers and it went amazingly well. I added 8 oz of plain applesauce (2 4oz snack cups) to keep the burgers moist. They do not taste sweet if you're concerned about that. I know the recipe says it makes 12 burgers but I got 15 decent sized burgers out of this recipe. Definitely will be a go to from now on.

text:
This recipe was passed on to me by my friend from work with the following changes.  Add 1 TBSP Worcestershire and 1 1/2 tsp liquid smoke plus added an extra garlic clove.  Let sit for 1 hr before forming patties. Grilled on George Foreman grill for 3 minutes.  For buns I sprayed "I can't believe it's not butter" spay onto 1 side of each piece of sliced sourdough bread and sprinkled with garlic salt.  Grilled buttered side on a flat non-stick pan. It's like a eating a burger from a restaurant.  My teenage sons and hubby say this is a keeper and asked me to make it again soon!

text:
This was really good. I added Cavender's seasoning to the meat mixture and sprinkled a light coating of the Montreal Steak Seasoning to the tops of the burgers as they cooked. To preserve the tenderness of the burgers and maintain juiciness, as they came out of the skillet, I loosely covered them in foil and put them in the oven. Mine was already hot from roasting sweet potatoes/onions but I turned it down to 325 and they stayed nice and juicy for the 10-15 min or so before serving them. I would definitely make them again.

userID:

Display Name:
Kitchenwarrior
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I liked this recipe a lot but I gave it four stars instead of five because I made some modifications.
I'm trying to eat as healthy and and flavorful as I possibly can so here's what I did.
3lbs turkey
1/2 diced red pepper
1 clove garlic
1/4 cup parsley
1/4 cup onion
1/8 cup thyme
1/8 cup sage
I sauted the pepper and onion for a couple of minutes in a little EVOO then added the garlic(don't cook the garlic for more than a minute or it will burn)
I mixed all that in the ground turkey with one whole brown egg along with the parsley, safe, and thyme.
I hand mixed it all up and formed (8) 1/2 inch thick, 5 inch wide patties and cooked them on my griddle until beautiful, brown grill marks formed.
I served these on lettuce instead of buns with homemade Greek yogurt ranch dressing and tomatoes. 
As a side I baked sweet potato "fries" and steamed broccoli.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made these last night.. delicious and easy! Even my picky son who eats NOTHING ate 2 of these burgers. I did add a splash of both worcheshire (sp?) and soy sauce. Also instead of minced garlic and onion I used powdered versions since my son isn't a fan of "chunks". Also used dried parsley instead of fresh. Before pan frying, I lightly coated each burger with some additional bread crumb just to help hold together as well as for a bit of texture. Used a whole egg also rather than just egg white. They were super easy to make, juicy and delicious. Didn't even really need any condiments, they were that good. Will definitely make again.

text:
Wow! These were really delicious! I used this recipe to teach me how to make turkey burgers but added a few more ingredients: Greek yogurt, and a dash of turmeric in addition to being too lazy to separate the yolk from the whites. I also baked these at 375 degrees for 30 mins (Turning halfway through)instead of pan frying. These were extremely moist and ended up being a huge hit. I suggest serving them over mixed greens with some tomato, avocado, cashews and your favorite dressing. Thanks for the wonderful starter recipe!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1887275.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG! So good. But I took the advice of some other reviewers. Added about 1/2 cup of red bell pepper, some soya sauce, some liquid smoke, 10 pulls off the Worcestershire, extra garlic, seasoning salt, extra parsley (not fresh),...and I took the advice of one reviewer that said to dip the patties in flour and then beat off the excess. I had never heard of this. I tried it! WOW! Doing this with all burgers. Got nice and crispy on the outside and didn't stick to the grill without any oil/pam! AMAZING. I made some authentic guacamole to put on the burgers, with havarti and tomatoes and lettuce. So good. Definitely a keeper. We keep making turkey burgers and every time they're better. Can't see them getting any better than this! I win the battle with my husband! ;) Oh yeah, i should mention I used garden flavour breton crackers instead of breadcrumbs! maybe that is the secret!

text:
Great recipe!  I don't like turkey burgers, so I was worried about the flavour, while trying to eat healthy.  So, I added a few shakes of sage, thyme, cayenne pepper, and Montreal Steak Spice, followed by a splash of Worcestershire sauce.  It did the trick.  I served the burger with guacamole(taken from Bob Cody's Guacamole recipe on this site) and some basic yellow mustard.  I loved it!  The kids liked the burger,but because they don't like avocado, I skipped avocado on their burgers.  No complaints, though.

I took advice from others to add  a few drops of hickory seasoning liquid smoke, a few drops of Worcestershire sauce and add a small, plastic package of soy sauce, leftover from a Chinese restaurant. I cant believe how good they turned out, this one is a keeper, thanks so much :)

These are *really* good. I cut down on the salt by about half (just what I do in almost everything) and I omit the onions (one son hates them and it's easy enough for everyone else to add). I think using them as called for would be even better. But the burgers are very flavorful and very moist - even when cooked on my George Foreman grill. I use only a few of turkey burger recipes all of which I have had to adjust to make perfect...except this one - it's good just as it is. Thank you!

text:
Yummy, first time making a burger.   Since I didn't have breadcrumbs, I used Wheat Germ instead.  I also left out the eggs.   Eggs and I just don't get along.  Given that, the patties did not fall apart.  I used a light coat of flour as insurance and then plopped it in an oiled grill pan.  The burger did poof up a bit, I should have used an iron press to make  it flatter, but once it was in my tummy, it was all good.   It almost tasted like a beef burger.  :)

text:
YES!!!  They actually are good turkey burgers.  I made these for a family get together and they were a big hit.  Everyone loved them.  I quadrupled the recipe and didn't have enough garlic so added a little pinch of garlic powder.  I didn't have fresh parsley so used half the called for amount of dried parsley and added some ginger root (about 1 tsp for a single recipe).  And just used 2 whole eggs for the quadrupled batch. So yummy.

region:

country:
None
text:
These were ok. I only made 4(1lb of turkey) and it was a little bland, needed a tad more salt for my taste. I didn't have seasoned breadcrums, just regular so added about half a teaspoon of mrs.dash to the mix, and i'm also trying to cut down on the fat so used fake eggs(what i call them, but they're really just egg whites i think) instead of the whole egg. I also didn't have fresh parsley so used about a teaspoon of dried, same goes for garlic, used 1/4ts. It was pretty good, but again a little bland for my taste. It wasn't dried out, yet not super moist either. I cooked in my George Foreman grill on low-med(i can adjust the temp) for about 8mins.

text:
This is the second time I've tried making turkey burgers and this recipe is so much better than the very first recipe I tried years ago.  When I thought the patties were done, I realized that they still needed a couple of more minutes, so I threw the lid on the skillet (for fear of drying them out) and they turned out moist.  I think this recipe is a great base to start out with.  I plan to play around with it by adding a few other ingredients to make this perfect for us!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/117407.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were actually really good! I accidentley bought some ground turkey & didn't know what to do with it so I gave this a try. I only had a pound & a half of meat so I used the same ingredients but I didn't measure anything, just eyeballed it. I also added a few splashes of soy sauce & worschisier sauce (however you spell it) & then the tiniest drop of hickory flavored liquid smoke & a few shakes of steak seasoning as some other reviewers had mentioned. I also added 2 cloves of garlic rather than 1 cause I love it! I formed my burgers then put them in the fridge until dinner time to help hold them together. I grilled these on my george forman grill & served with american cheese, red onion & lettace. My turkey hating hubby was so not looking forward to trying these, but once we tried them they were actually pretty darn good! He said if I didn't tell him it was turkey he wouldn't have even known!! Now I can make turkey burgers on occasion as a healthier alternative to beef! Next time I think I'm going to chop up some fresh mushrooms & mix that in & serve with swiss cheese that sounds delish! Thanks for the surprisingly great recipe, we really enjoyed it :)
Review:

5

text:
Amazing great recipe!  However, instead of the original print mine!  Its is 10,000 times better.  Instead of ground turkey I used filet and skipped the bun.  I used the parsley as a garnish and salted the mashed potatoes i made with it.  Instead of bread crumbs, I used some fresh rolls as an appetizer.  Made a hollandaise from scratch for the filet.  Add some fresh asparagus.  Place filet on asparagus and potatoes, drizzle with hollandaise and it makes for a fantastic turkey burger!  Enjoy!!!

For 1 lb of ground turkey, making 4 burgers:  ~3 Tbsp onion, handful of parsley, 1/4 cup bread crumbs, 2 garlic cloves (this may have been too much), salt, pepper, seasoning salt, some worcestershire sauce.  I did lightly flour the patties before frying, 6 mins/side.  Served with lettuce, tomato, mayo on wheat rolls.  Yum!

AMAZING!! I omitted the parsley as I did not have it on hand. I also added 1/2 a cup of chopped red bell pepper and with the recommendations of other reviewers, added a couple of splashed of Worcestershire Sauce and low sodium soy sauce. I used a whole egg instead of just egg whites and added a little more bread crumbs. I grilled these on my George Foreman and served with mini sliders! These were delicious, so juicy, and as I grilled them it filled my kitchen with delicious smells that made my mouth water!   My mother cannot eat beef and these were a great substitution! Will definitely make again!

text:
These were really good!  This was my first time experimenting with ground turkey instead of beef.  I scaled down to 1 lb. of turkey and still got 5 nice size burgers out of this.  They didn't shrink up like the beef ones do.  I only had dried parsley, and I just added one whole egg instead of egg whites.  I also tossed in chopped red peppers and a little bit of leftover reduced fat feta cheese, which was delicious in these -- melted down beautifully and no need to add any extra cheese to your burger!  We grilled these on the George Foreman and it worked great!

text:
Excellent turkey burger.  I followed the directions except I used old bay seasoned bread crumbs and seasoned salt in place of regular salt.  The fresh ingredients really made a difference in my opinion.  I made 10 burgers out of this batch and cooked them on my George Foreman grill on medium for 15 min.  Served the burgers on wheat hamburger rolls with sauteed onions, shredded lettuce and sliced tomatoes.  We had sauteed spinich with garlic on the side.  My family loved these burgers.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2009-03-17T19:04:15.727
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
1783160
Display Name:
Aims
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
32
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1129969.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good recipe with the following additions... add 1 tablespoon soy sauce, 2 drops liquid smoke, 2 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce, 1 teaspoon season-all, 1 tablespoon Montreal steak seasoning, 1 teaspoon garlic powder, 1 tablespoon sweet basil in place of parsley a-n-d if you want a lil extra kick, add some spicy brown mustard to the meat mixture. Use the whole egg and grind saltines into crumbs and add 1 teaspoon italian seasoning or try chicken flavored stuffing mix ground into crumbs. Serve with finely sliced baby spinach (like shredded lettuce) petite diced or thinly sliced tomatoes and some feta cheese.  For those having an issue with the burgers being dry, try one of the follow...  Grilling: add a couple tablespoons of very finely crushed iced right into the meat mixture.  Frying: place in a frying pan and add 1/2 cup water, cover with a lid and simmer until your desired doneness is reached. (You could even use turkey or chicken broth)

text:
These burgers were SO GOOD! I used ground turkey breast so I was a bit nervous they would be dry. That wasn't the case at all.   I made a couple of small changes. I didn't have any parsley so I used about a 1/4 cup of finely diced green pepper. I also put in a splash of Worcestershire sauce. I think I'm going to put in a splash of liquid smoke next time to "beef" it up a little bit.  My husband said we should have a weekly burger night with these! My four and six year old gobbled them up too. Oh, I made our burgers with sauteed (in 1 tsp of olive oil) mushrooms and onions and a slice of Jarlsberg lite cheese.

These were very good.  I am giving it 4 stars because I made two changes. I will make these again! Thanks for the recipe.

text:
this recipe was great!!  I used suggestions from other users: wortchesire sauce-sp?, lawry's seasoning salt, some extra pepper.  I didn't have the minced garlic but it was great anyway.  I was very suprised by how much parsley to use but it was wonderful.  Then I mashed up half an avacado with a teaspoon of mayo and salt & pepper and used it as a spread.  One word YUMMY!!!
p.s. I used 1 pd of turkey and I made 4 patties on my griddle.  If you can't get the inside done put something over it to capture the steam.

text:
These burgers were really delicious, even my husband enjoyed them!  I made a few changes (scaled down for 1 lb. of meat)...added a small handful more breadcrumbs, used seasoned salt instead of reg. salt, put about 5 or 7 shakes each of lite soy sauce and Worcestershire, and I left my onion a little larger than a fine dice (to add a little texture).  I also put them in the freezer for about 15 mins. before grilling, really helped them stay together.  They were great, this one is a keeper for me!

userID:
666613
Display Name:
ICEFIRE1
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0

5
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Much better than the turkey patties you buy in the store.
I bought 3 packages of "Honeysuckle White" ground turkey (about 3 1/2 lbs.)
I used 1/3 cup regular breadcrumbs instead of 1/4 cup.
Everything else according to recipe except added a few drops of liquid smoke, a few drops of soy sauce, and a few drops of worcestershire sauce.
Don't cook in a skillet - much better on the grill - scrape the grill clean then pour some olive oil on a paper towel and wipe the grates with it.
Oh yeah, keep your hands wet (water) when making 12 patties. Make the patties the day before and put between wax paper.
These burgers are awesome!

5

Like most people, I altered the recipe a little, since I didn't have all the ingredients, plus I seasoned to taste.  
The basic recipe is great to build on.  I didn't expect it to taste like beef; I wasn't quite sure what I was expecting.  The idea of turkey burgers never appealed to me, however, I thought I'd give it a try, since I want to eat healthier.  The burgers were great!  I ate them bunless, with only a little barbeque sauce, some of which I added to the meat before cooking.  I thought they were great, even though I didn't cover them up with a bun, and tons of condiments.
Review:

5

I made a few alterations so if it hadn't turned out I wouldn't have reviewed, but they were delicious so here goes:  I didn't have bread crumbs so I added a little more wheat germ than was called for in the recipe, added about a TBS of worchestire sauce, used dried parsley, and the whole egg as suggested.  These were wonderful!  I usually buy the prepared ones, but these were tender and juicy with great flavor.  One note, they seem very soft and I had to shape them right on the pan but they kept together perfectly and didn't crumble at all.  My two year old ate an entire one!

text:
I have to laugh over the "actually" delicious as though turkey can't be delicious.  I make things like turkey burgers, white chili, etc. all the time.  (And I'm supposed to be the picky eater.)  It really helps if you can just take turkey for what it is: turkey, and stop seeing it as a beef substitute.  I made these as is.  They were good, but (despite being "actually" delicious), I've had better.  Turkey requires extra moisture and extra flavor since it's bland.  I think this was missing just a little something on the "extra flavor" side.

country:
None
text:
Just one thing that makes a huge difference, the first time I made them I followed the recipe, pretty good.  I made them again and added about 10 chopped up button mushrooms and 2 green onions white and green part and omitted read crumbs.  The mushrooms retain a lot of moisture and made them so much moister.  Oh yeah, I also added a heaping tablespoon of good quality dijon mustard to the mix.  They were great on a toasted wheat bun with some lettuce, fresh salsa and avocado on top. My husband topped his with swiss cheese and barbeque sauce.  Men!
Also, they are a little "soft" for the outdoor grill, better inside on a grill pan lightly sprayed.

text:
This was an excellent recipe.  I will definitely be using it again. My husband said it was the best burger he'd ever had and my finicky toddler gobbled up his burger. 
I love experimenting with recipes so here's how I gave my burgers their extra umph: 1) I used some ground steak spice (You can use a magic bullet or coffee grinder) 2) I used seasoning salt instead of the salt and pepper. 3) I took on reviewers suggestions and added worcheshire sauce and hot sauce.
4) I served the burgers with avacado, tomato, lettuce and sauted mushrooms and onions (saute with a 1/2 tsp. of hickory flavoured sauce, a dash of salt and pepper), I used mayo, dijon mustard, and cranberry sauce as well.  Awesome!!

text:
I've never made Turkey burgers before, but we had some friends over that don't eat any red meat, so I thought I would try this recipe.  The only changes we made only because we use this for our beef burgers was to add some worshershire, omitted the salt and garlic and added garlic powder along with ground pepper and mixed in some ice cold water to make a juicy burger.  They loved them and so did I.  We will make these a lot more often for a healthier burger.  Thanks so much for the post.

They are "actually delicious"!  Nice and juicy as long as you don't over cook them.  I added Worcestershire Sauce, 2 whole eggs, plain bread crumbs (instead of seasoned), paprika and a little extra garlic.  I also added bbq sauce to a few while they cooked for extra flavour.  Melted some med. cheddar cheese on the top; a bit high in calories but oh so good!
